prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB x B_ -> 4/4 B_
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG
Blue x Turquoise -> 1/2 Blue 1/2 Turquoise

data.expected: Bt x BT -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BT, 1/4 TT
data.sampled: BB x BB -> 1/4 BG, 1/4 BB, 1/2 TT

Here is a table of the possible crosses and their results:

| Parent 1 | Blue | Green | Turquoise |
|---------|------|-------|----------|
| Parent 2 | Blue | Green | Turquoise |
| F1      | BT    | GT     | BG       |

Note that this is impossible, as the F1 generation should have a 3:1 ratio of green to turquoise, but it has a 1:1 ratio instead. Iyou can correct this by changing the question.

prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB x B_ -> 4/4 B_
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG
Blue x Gree -> 1/2 Blue 1/2 Green

data.expected: GT (Green) x GT (Green) -> 1/4 GG (Green), 1/2 GT (Green), 1/4 TT (Turquoise)
data.sampled:
Impossible. This is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. It is not possible to have a genotype of TT, as it would not be compatible with the dominance hierarchy (T > G > B). Therefore, it is impossible to obtain a turquoise phenotype in a cross between two green individuals.

The correct genotypic ratios for the offspring of a cross between two blue individuals are: 1/4 BB (Blue), 1/2 BG (Blue/Green), 1/4 GG (Green).

prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB x B_ -> 4/4 B_
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG
Blue x Green -> 1/2 Blue 1/4 Green 1/4 Turquoise

options: BT x GT -> 1/4 BG, 1/4 BT, 1/4 GT, 1/4 TT

data.expected: BG (Blue) x BG (Blue) -> 1/4 BB (Blue), 1/2 BG (Blue), 1/4 GG (Green)
data.sampled:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green can be rewritten as follows:
```obj
B_ (Blue) x B_ (Blue) -> 1/4 B_ (Blue), 1/4 BG (Green), 1/4 GG (Green), 1/4 G_ (Green)
```
The correct order of the phenotypes in the F1 generation should be:
```css
BB (Blue) x BG (Blue Green) -> 1/4 BB (Blue), 1/2 BG (Blue Green), 1/4 GG (Green)
```
Therefore, the parent genotypes are:
```css
BB (Blue) x BG (Blue Green)
```
and the F1 genotypes are:
```obj
BG (Blue Green)
BG (Blue Green)
BG (Blue Green)
GG (Green)
```
Note: B_ represents homozygous dominant B allele, BG represents heterozygous state, GG represents homozygous recessive G allele.
